questions.text: Which of the following radioisotopes is used in a PET-CT scan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

18F-FDG

18F-FDG is the radioisotope used in a PET-CT scan.

questions.text: What is the ideal thickness of lead aprons to be worn by workers associated with radiographical procedures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

0.5mm

The lead apron to be worn by workers associated with radiographical procedures should contain 0.5 mm of lead.

questions.text: X-ray of a patient appears as below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lung collapse

In the provided X-ray image, there is evidence of complete opacification (whitening) of the left lung field, along with a shift of the mediastinum (central structure in the chest containing the heart and major blood vessels) towards the affected side. These findings are indicative of a lung collapse, also known as atelectasis.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. His CT scan is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Subdural hemorrhage

The given CT image shows a crescent-shaped lesion that crosses suture lines and is indicative of acute subdural hematoma/hemorrhage. Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Most commonly, it results from the rupture of cortical bridging veins. Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

choices.text: A. Kidney, B. Liver, C. Pancreas
A. Liver, B. Pancreas, C. Spleen
A. Spleen, B. Kidney, C. Liver
A. Pancreas, B. Liver, C. Spleen

questions.text: Identify the correct anatomies from the CT scan given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A. Liver, B. Pancreas, C. Spleen

The correct identification of structures marked as A, B, and C in the CT image is: A-Liver, B-Pancreas, C-Spleen.

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Vomiting is a late adverse reaction
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
All the adverse effects are reversible

questions.text: Which of the following is true about radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the squared distance from the source of radiation. This is known as the inverse square law in radiotherapy.

questions.text: A patient presented after a road traffic accident (RTA) with a head injury. CT head is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Depressed skull fracture

The clinical history and the CT image are suggestive of a depressed skull fracture of the left frontal bone. A depressed skull fracture occurs when a portion of the skull is pushed inward due to trauma, creating a depression in the bone. This type of fracture can occur as a result of a direct impact to the head, such as in a road traffic accident.

questions.text: The principle of linear accelerators is used in the production of ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

X-rays are the most common form of radiation used in radiotherapy. They are produced from LINAC (Linear Accelerator).

questions.text: The radiological imaging of choice for pheochromocytoma is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

MRI is the investigation of choice for localizing the tumor in pheochromocytoma. Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor derived from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the arrow.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Right 4th Posterior Rib

questions.text: A patient met with a Road traffic accident, presents in an unconscious state. BP is normal and an NCCT image obtained is given below likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

EDH

Associated with skull fractures:

• Biconvex collection

• Limited by sutures

• Not limited by dural reflection–can cross the midline

• Middle meningeal artery (source)

Swirl Sign- due to active bleed in EDH seen as hypodense area in hyperdense bleed on NCCT.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure on the given CT scan image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Maxillary sinus

Waters‘ view is a radiographic view of the skull. It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses. An x-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure on the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

First part of duodenum

questions.text: A cancer patient undergoing Radiotherapy is given a dose of 1.8-2 Gy once daily for 5 days per week for a duration of 6-8 weeks. What is this type of radiotherapy called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Regular Fractionated Radiotherapy/Conventional

Type of radiotherapy-

•	Regular Fractionated radiotherapy- treatment are divided into small dose and given over several weeks so that normal cell gets time to repair between treatment

•	Radical radiotherapy-early stage of cancer is an aim to cure.

•	Adjuvant radiotherapy- to improve the result of other treatments usually surgery. 

•	Accelerated radiotherapy- it is used for the treatment of head and neck cancer

•	Hypofractionated radiotherapy- treatment is divided into large dose and given less often. It reduces side effects and it is cost effecting.

questions.text: Identify the structure in the given image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Jejunum

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with complaints of daily purulent sputum production. On examination wheezing sound is heard. Identify the condition given in this image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bronchiectasis

questions.text: What does the following X-ray depict?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tension pneumothorax

Life-threatening condition as it causes adverse effects on gas exchange (intra-pleural pressure +ve relative to atmosphere)

Signs on X-ray 

• Contralateral mediastinal shift

• Depressed diaphragm (more reliable sign) (Figure)

Pneumo-mediastinum-Signs on X-ray

• Undue clarity of mediastinal border

• Air outlining thymus (Spinnaker sail sign)

• Air around pulmonary artery (ring sign)

• Air around bronchi (double bronchial wall sign).

questions.text: Identify the view given in the X-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Water view

questions.text: Identify the condition given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pott’s spine

Aka- tuberculosis of the spine.

questions.text: Identify the given modality: -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

MRI of Polycystic Kidney disease

Given image shows MRI scan. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the commonest inherited renal disorder.

Air and hard bone do not give an MRI signal so these areas appear black. Bone marrow, spinal fluid, blood, and soft tissues vary in intensity from black to white, depending on the amount of fat and water present in each tissue and the machine settings used for the scan.

questions.text: Diagnose the pathology given on the barium image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diffuse Esophageal spasm

Diffuse/distal esophageal spasm (DOS) is a motility disorder of the esophagus. On barium swallow, the diffuse esophageal spasm may appear as a corkscrew esophagus.

Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES), also known as distal esophageal spasm, is a condition characterized by uncoordinated contractions of the esophagus, which may cause difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) or regurgitation.

questions.text: Identify the site of the foreign body as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Esophagus

•Esophageal foreign bodies cause dysphagia and sometimes lead to perforation. Diagnosis is clinical, but imaging studies and endoscopy may be needed.

•Foreign bodies in the upper esophagus are more accurately localized by the patient.

questions.text: A 35-years old female presented to the emergency room with upper abdominal pain radiating to the back, On X-Ray a colon cut-off sign is seen. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Acute Pancreatitis

The colon cutoff sign describes the abrupt termination of gas within the proximal colon caused by a functional spasm of infiltrating the phrenicocolic ligament. The presence of the colon cutoff sign on radiography is usually related to acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Perthe's Disease

•	The typical findings of advanced burnt out (stage 4) Perthes disease are: femoral head deformity with widening and flattening (coxa plana) proximal femoral neck deformity: coxa magna. "sagging rope sign" (thin sclerotic line running across the femoral neck)

•	Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, refers to idiopathic osteonecrosis of the femoral epiphysis seen in children. It should not be confused with a Perthes lesion of the shoulder.

questions.text: Identify the marked bone in X-ray of feet shown:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Navicular

The navicular is a wedge-shaped bone that articulates with five tarsal bones forming syndesmotic joints. It is located in the midfoot together with the cuboid and three cuneiform bones.

questions.text: Canon ball opacities as shown in the given chest X-Ray image indicate:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pulmonary metastasis

“Cannonball appearance,” feature of Pulmonary Metastasis.

questions.text: A chest X-ray from a patient of covid-19 would show:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ground glass opacity (GGO)

Ground-glass opacity (GGO) - a hazy, gray appearing density on computed tomography (CT) of lungs - is one of the hallmark features of SARS-CoV-2 in COVID-19 patients.

questions.text: Which lobe consolidation is shown in the shown radiograph?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

RML

The silhouette sign refers to the loss of normal borders between thoracic structures. It is usually caused by an intrathoracic radiopaque mass that touches the border of the heart or aorta. Look at the area of consolidation it is silhouetting the right heart middle lobe border

questions.text: Identify the pathology shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Achalasia cardia

Achalasia cardia smooth tappering at the end of esophagus without any shouldering.

Rat-tail appearance on barium swallow is a characteristic sign of achalasia cardia but rarely it can occur due to other causes like carcinoma of esophagus and in infections like tuberculosis or chagas disease.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in given radiograph:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Congenital diaphragmatic Hernia

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) occurs when there is a hole in the diaphragm, which is the thin sheet of muscle separating the chest from the abdomen. When this gap forms during a fetus's development in the womb, the bowel, stomach or even the liver can move into the chest cavity.

questions.text: Identify the condition on shown radiograph:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Perforation Peritonitis

Pneumoperitoneum refers to presence of free air within the peritoneal cavity, “Pneumoperitoneum induced Peritonitis” is synonymous of surgical pneumoperitoneum, as the leak of air and visceral contents contaminates the peritoneal cavity, producing peritonitis which mandates surgery.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on shown radiograph?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Diverticulosis

Sawtooth appearance on barium enema multiple outpouchings can be seen mainly towards the mesenteric side is associated with Diverticulosis.

questions.text: What is showing in Radiograph?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cardiac pacemaker in right ventricle

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in given radiograph?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A tension pneumothorax will have the same features as a simple pneumothorax with a number of additional features, helpful in identifying tension. These additional signs indicate hyper expansion of the hemithorax:

• Ipsilateral increased intercostal spaces

• Contralateral shift of the mediastinum

• Depression of the hemidiaphragm

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in given radiograph: -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bladder Stone

Shown radiograph is of bladder stone

Usually densely radiopaque, calculi may be single or multiple and are often large. Frequently lamination is observed internally, like the skin of an onion.

questions.text: Which arterial territory is involved on this CT scan image of a patient with infarct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Complete middle cerebral artery

Extensive infarction of subacute aspect, in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery is seen without hemorrhagic transformation and no significant mass effect.

questions.text: A patient comes to the emergency room vomiting and with colicky abdominal pain. On investigation following image is obtained. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Horse shoe kidney

The image shows fusion of left and right kidney referred to as Horse shoe kidney.

Horseshoe kidneys are the most common fusion defect of the kidneys occurring in approximately 1:500 individuals. They are characterized by abnormalities in the position, rotation, and vascular supply of the kidney. Although largely benign, they are associated with urological sequelae due largely to the associated ureteric obstruction and impaired urinary drainage.

questions.text: Most radiosensitive bone tumor
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ewing Sarcoma

Ewing's sarcoma is the most radiosensitive of the bone sarcomas.

questions.text: A patient presented with epistaxis and was diagnosed with Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma. What is the sign demonstrated in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Holman Miller Sign

The image shows anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus in Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is Holman Miller Sign.

questions.text: A patient with a history of TB, and prolonged back pain. Diagnosis as per radiograph would be:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Psoas Abscess

The image shows fluid accumulation in the psoas muscle. Psoas (or iliopsoas) abscess is a collection of pus in the iliopsoas muscle compartment. It may arise via contiguous spread from adjacent structures or by the hematogenous route from a distant site. Here it is caused by TB.

questions.text: Identify the given image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hydatidiform mole

The image shows snowstorm appearance. Classically, a 'snowstorm pattern' has been described, resulting from the presence of a complex vesicular intrauterine mass containing many 'grape-like' cysts. Ultrasound evaluation of the adnexa can also reveal theca lutein cysts, due to ovarian stimulation by abnormally elevated beta-hCG levels.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the given radiograph?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rickets

The image shows cupping, splaying and fraying of the growth plate suggests rickets.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient on irregular medication has a headache and a BP 220/110 mmhg. CT head is shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Putaminal Bleed

Most common site of hypertensive bleed is putamen

questions.text: Identify the marked structure on CT Head:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Optic Nerve

Computed tomography scan of optic nerve head showing calcification of the optic disc in both eyes.

questions.text: A X-ray of a 2-year-old child is given. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pneumoperitoneum

The football sign is seen in cases of massive pneumoperitoneum, where the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus. In the duodenal atresia double bubble sign is seen. In Subcutaneous Emphysema leaf sign is seen.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female presents with fever, weight loss, and elevated levels of ACE levels with hilar lymphadenopathy on x-ray, the most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sarcoidosis

In the radiograph, there is bilateral hilar lymph nodes and an increase in the level of ACE diagnosis it sarcoidosis. On gallium scan, the galium uptake in bilateral hilarious lymph nodes and para tracheal lymph nodes gives lambda sign in sarcoidosis.

questions.text: Identify the structure being pointed by the arrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Portal Vein

questions.text: Prophylactic craniospinal irradiation is done for which cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Small cell lung cancer

Craniospinal Irradiation is done in medulloblastoma, pineoblastoma, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, ALL, and small cell cancer. Growth hormone deficiency occurs after craniospinal irradiation.

questions.text: Identify the anomaly given on the X-ray given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hydropneumothorax

•	Hydropneumothorax is the abnormal presence of air and fluid in the pleural space.

•	On an erect chest radiograph, recognition of hydropneumothorax can be rather easy and classically shows as a gas-fluid level. 

•	On the supine radiograph, this may be more challenging where a sharp pleural line is bordered by increased opacity lateral to it within the pleural space may sometimes suggest towards the diagnosis.
